Complete the following Lean 4 code:
```lean4
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Matrix

abbrev putnam_2011_a4_solution : Set ℕ := sorry
-- {n : ℕ | Odd n}
/--
For which positive integers $n$ is there an $n \times n$ matrix with integer entries such that every dot product of a row with itself is even, while every dot product of two different rows is odd?
-/
theorem putnam_2011_a4
    (nmat : ℕ → Prop)
    (hnmat : ∀ n, nmat n ↔
      ∃ A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℤ,
        (∀ r, Even ((A r) ⬝ᵥ (A r))) ∧
        Pairwise fun r1 r2 ↦ Odd ((A r1) ⬝ᵥ (A r2)))
    (n : ℕ) (npos : 0 < n) :
    nmat n ↔ n ∈ putnam_2011_a4_solution :=
  sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_2011_a4
    (nmat : ℕ → Prop)
    (hnmat : ∀ n, nmat n ↔
      ∃ A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℤ,
        (∀ r, Even ((A r) ⬝ᵥ (A r))) ∧
        Pairwise fun r1 r2 ↦ Odd ((A r1) ⬝ᵥ (A r2)))
    (n : ℕ) (npos : 0 < n) :
    nmat n ↔ n ∈ putnam_2011_a4_solution := by
  rw [hnmat]
  constructor
  · rintro ⟨A, hA1, hA2⟩
    simp_all [putnam_2011_a4_solution, Nat.odd_iff_not_even, even_iff_two_dvd, Nat.even_iff]
    <;> aesop
  · intro h
    match n with
    | 0 => contradiction
    | 1 =>
      use fun i j => 0
      simp_all [Matrix.dotProduct, Fin.sum_univ_succ, even_iff_two_dvd, Nat.even_iff]
      <;> aesop
    | k + 2 =>
      use fun i j => if i = j then 0 else 1
      simp_all [Matrix.dotProduct, Fin.sum_univ_succ, even_iff_two_dvd, Nat.even_iff]
      <;>
        aesop
```

```lean4
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Matrix

abbrev putnam_2011_a4_solution : Set ℕ := sorry
-- {n : ℕ | Odd n}
/--
For which positive integers $n$ is there an $n \times n$ matrix with integer entries such that every dot product of a row with itself is even, while every dot product of two different rows is odd?
-/
theorem putnam_2011_a4
    (nmat : ℕ → Prop)
    (hnmat : ∀ n, nmat n ↔
      ∃ A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℤ,
        (∀ r, Even ((A r) ⬝ᵥ (A r))) ∧
        Pairwise fun r1 r2 ↦ Odd ((A r1) ⬝ᵥ (A r2)))
    (n : ℕ) (npos : 0 < n) :
    nmat n ↔ n ∈ putnam_2011_a4_solution :=
  sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_2011_a4
    (nmat : ℕ → Prop)
    (hnmat : ∀ n, nmat n ↔
      ∃ A : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℤ,
        (∀ r, Even ((A r) ⬝ᵥ (A r))) ∧
        Pairwise fun r1 r2 ↦ Odd ((A r1) ⬝ᵥ (A r2)))
    (n : ℕ) (npos : 0 < n) :
    nmat n ↔ n ∈ putnam_2011_a4_solution := by
  rw [hnmat]
  constructor
  -- Case 1: If nmat n is true, then n must be even.
  · rintro ⟨A, hA1, hA2⟩
    simp_all [Even, Odd, Nat.even_iff, Nat.odd_iff_not_even]
    -- Use the properties of the matrix A to show that n must be even.
    <;>
    induction n with
    | zero => contradiction -- n = 0 is impossible since npos : 0 < n.
    | succ n ih =>
      cases n with
      | zero =>
        -- For n = 1, we need to check the conditions.
        simp_all [Matrix.dotProduct, Fin.sum_univ_succ]
        <;>
        omega
      | succ n =>
        -- For n > 1, use the induction hypothesis and properties of the matrix.
        simp_all [Matrix.dotProduct, Fin.sum_univ_succ]
        <;>
        omega
  -- Case 2: If n is even, then nmat n is true.
  · rintro h
    simp_all [Even, Odd, Nat.even_iff, Nat.odd_iff_not_even]
    -- Construct a matrix A that satisfies the conditions for an even n.
    <;>
    use fun i j => if i = j then 2 else 1
    <;>
    simp_all [Matrix.dotProduct, Fin.sum_univ_succ, Finset.sum_ite, Finset.filter_eq, Finset.filter_ne,
      Finset.sum_const, Finset.card_fin, Finset.card_filter]
    <;>
    norm_num
    <;>
    omega
```
